column27: I think that the reason Sam feels like he/she is going to cry is because of frustration for losing their project that they have been working so hard on and a bit disappointed in themselves because he/she doesn't think it'll be done now by the deadline.

column9: I feel like I want to help Sam because I know what it feels like to have bad day.

frustration with the situation; but also in the slightly unprofessional way the e-mail has been written; empathy because this guy is now put into a really tough position; curiosity because I want to find Lewis and get his side of the story; so as to make a better judgement of weather or not he actually did give details for the campaign away. column27: These feelings all revolve around the fact that this situation is now out of his control; despite the hard work he has put into it.
column84: This participant laughed when I told her that she would be best suited for the manager position--during the debrief she told me that she was not at all qualified for the position and that she thought that the experiment was about gender roles in business; specifically with female managers and male employees.  / She gave painfully poor directions to the other participant and it was clear that she was very nervous about being manager.  The other participant was asking several questions to make her poor directions more clear.  It seemed as though she felt more low power than the other participant while the other person seemed more high power.  There was a tension between the participant because of the poor directions.
Participant was shocked that this was not about workplace behavior.

column9: I feel sympathetic for Sam because I can relate to the feeling that occurs when an important document is lost. Lastly; I question this email because there is no proof that he lost his whole project or even had it done besides his written word.

column25: he is really down on his luck

column27: Despair because he's in such a bind and at such a loss of what to do; confusion because he really doesn't know what's going on; and frustration because there's no easy way to resolve this

column27: Sam basically has to complete the rest of the project the project by herself.

I feel like this is a problem out of Sam's hands that he/she did not cause. It also needs to be resolved in a short amount of time so that adds stress to the situation as well. column27: Sam seems to feel very stressed about the situation. While he/she is concerned about Lewis and his actions; those feelings seem secondary to the project due date and work that needs to be done with that. It appears as if that is the main cause of stress at the moment.

column27: He/she is pissed that Lewis could have betrayed them like this; and irritated because he/she is left picking up the pieces; and lost because he/she has no idea what to do and can't stay calm so he/she isn't thinking clearly enough to respond effectively.

column84: Subject told me he had been awake for over 48 hours before the study began.

column9: Would like to help; but know that I can't.

I am concerned for Sam and our company and I am upset that Sam has been put in a difficult situation possibly possibly because of Lewis's actions. However; I am staying positive and open minded to the fact that it could be a coincidence. I would suggest for Sam to talk to Lewis about what happened.

column27: Based on the e-mail; Sam is very nervous about what will happen next along with anxious.  She is obviously angry based on the fact she is fuming.

column9: I am not fuming; but I am slightly angry that Lewis betrayed the company and put Sam in a bad position. However; I would like to find out more before I act.

I feel conflicted.  I believe in school; we are strictly taught to adhere to no extensions for late assignments and in some cases a teacher would not expect a power outage as an excuse.  However me personally; understand that things happen and sometimes outcomes can not be predicted or controlled so I understand the position the worker is in and would be obliged to give them more time.  However I say I have doubt as to if the story is the complete truth; because; in the e-mail he/she mentions how sad she is and how the problem occurred but nothing about how he/she would solve it.  Perhaps he or she just does not want to do it.
column27: The worker talks a ton about how he or she is crying and how awful he or she feels showing sadness.  All the mention of crying and how they don't know what they or going to do seems like they have self-pitty. Lastly I believe conflicted; because the worker mentions before leaving for work noticing the computer hard drive was dead; but not being able to find his flash drive anywhere.  Then when he came back his computer turned on and his flash drive was in the computer; with no mention of how he had not seen it in the first place.  To me this seems odd.

column9: I am thoughtful and determined because I immediately started to think of ways to try to help Sam recover his presentation or how long it would take me and others to help Sam recreate the project.

I said sorry because I feel a little bad for Sam. Petty may not be the right word but basically I feel like he is jumping to blaming Lewis without enough evidence. Revenge because I feel like she is feeling she wants to get back at lewis

column9: I feel regret because; according to his story at least; it was an honest mistake; and he's going to have to face some consequences no matter what.

I have been in a similar situation before; and can empathize with how frustrating and scary an experience like that is. Secondly; I ma nervous about both how Sam is going to handle the situation and whether he will be able to grow and learn from this experience or whether it will significantly affect his emotional well being and ability to perform in the workplace. Finally; I am determined to make sure we move forward and handle the situation the best way we can; which will include an efficient search for Sam's flash drive; consulting the IT or other departments to assess whether the hard drive can be restored; and if all else fails; reconstructing Sam's project from scratch.
column27: Sam is likely scared because he does not know what the consequences of this will be; sad because of all the work poured into this project and how easily it all got lost; and stressed due to his inability to stop thinking about this misfortune in combination with the realization of potential consequences for being behind on a major piece of work
column84: He realized that it might be about the power dynamic and maybe how as a manager you would have a different response to the situation in the email. Didn't really connect it to emotions but guessed that the power dynamic was being tested.

column9: I feel like i must be wanted Sam for him to email me; and that he would only be doing so if he believed i could help. I also feel like Sam and i are in this together to deal with Lewis.
column27: Sam seems to be pressed for time and annoyed that he is in the situation he is in. I also feel that he is rushing to rash accusations before settling down to think them over

column9: Sam's situation reminds me of when i lose my work or fall very behind on my schedules. Even though I know that I need to stay calm to be productive; I have a hard time pulling myself together.
I feel bad that they lost their work on the project; and I would be willing to help them work on it to finish it on time.
I'm upset because she is having a tough time handling the situation. I'm optimistic that she will finish it despite this set back.  I feel willing to help her complete this if need be.
I feel bad for Sam; since his project was ruined by Lewis. Lewis seems to have sent the slogan to another company and proceeded to quit his job at Fly For All to work for the competitor.

column84: He figured out that the study was looking at power and how that influenced your emotional response to the email. I also know him from one of my classes.

column9: I am trying not to jump to any conclusions based on the viewpoint of just Sam. I would want to talk to Lewis and see what he has to say. I am also trying to think about other ways the competing company could have gotten the information. However I do feel bad for Sam; because he worked hard on the idea and now he cannot use it.
column27: Well Sam is clearly upset with his co-worker because he thinks he stole his idea for a marketing campaign. He is "fuming".

column9: I am curious as to what the real story is; i would like to find out more details; and get to the bottom of the situation.
column27: They didnt know how their boss would react and was nervous about the result

column9: This is definitely an unusual situation so I'm interested to find out more details about it.

It sounds like Sam is in a "murphy's law" situation - everything that could've gone wrong for him has gone wrong. I've been in this position before and I know how awful it can be. At the same time; the amount of things that went wrong at once is a little bit funny.
he is screwed
column27: he just lost everything

column9: I feel sorry that Sam lost all the work and want to help with making it again or finding out if there is a way to get it back and I am anxious in doing so.
column27: Confused as in didn't know what to do about the situation.

column9: Stressed about school work

I'm curious as to the other side of the story (Lewis'). I'm eager to help Sam resolve this content and I am content knowing this is a fake email and this issue is not one that I will need to deal with in real life.
column27: He had nowhere else to turn and seemed to use me as a last ditch effort to resolve his issue.

column84: When I asked him if the was more to this study; he talked about how assigning roles must have been trying to make the participants have a power struggle and that he did not feel like he was above the other participant because he believed this was randomly done.  He found it very difficult to talk about how the email made Sam feel because he does not know the type of person Sam is and it is just a piece of paper to him.

column9: I really do understand the person's problem in this situation. It must be really difficult; but also slightly upset that they didn't take extra precautions with this work. With really important work; it should have many backups. However; it is also not a time to put blame on anyone as there really isn't much anyone could have done; likewise it is best to stay calm throughout the situation.
column27: The person is very upset and frustrated clearly because they did not have control over what happened to all their hard work. They might feel like a failure because they were responsible for doing something and they couldn't get it done.

column9: This seems like an unfortunate situation. It appears Lewis was highly unethical; however; I feel that I must remain even-handed and skeptical. A possibility exists that Sam might in fact have been the one to have sent the information to the competitor company in an effort to sabotage Lewis. I would need more information to make an accurate assessment and verify if Sam's claims are true.
column84: It was clear that this participant was frustrated with the poor directions of the "manager" and had to ask multiple questions.  It seemed that he viewed himself more as the "high power" because of her poor directions (these were painfully poor directions).
203-2 (other participant) never showed up; cancelled study.
203-2 never showed up for study; canceled study.
